Understanding the stcmd Command Line

The stcmd command line comes with the Windows and the Cross-Platform clients and has the same commands in both clients.

You can perform command-line operations from:

  • A command-line session using the command stcmd and the appropriate options.

  • Any development environment that allows you to add tools to menus.

A Server must be accessible and running the server configuration whose projects are to be accessed.

Syntax

In this Help system, the command-line syntax uses the following conventions:

Bold type indicates information that you must use exactly as shown (if you use it).

Italic type  indicates information that you replace with the names of your files, child folders, etc.

[ ] Optional information appears in square brackets.

| A vertical bar separates mutually exclusive choices. You select only one of the choices.

Operations

The operations are:

Add files (stcmd add)

Add folders (stcmd add-folder)

Add projects (stcmd add-project)

Add views (stcmd add-view)

Apply labels to selected files (stcmd apply label)

Check in files (stcmd ci)

Check out files (stcmd co)

Delete files from the working folder (stcmd delete local)

Display the differences between two revisions of a file (stcmd diff)

Change description (stcmd dsc)

Display revision history of files (stcmd hist)

Create a new label for a view (stcmd label)

Lock or unlock files (stcmd lck)

List files (stcmd list)

Create working folders (stcmd local mkdir)

Merging files (vismerge)

Move file status information from the server to the client as part of upgrading to StarTeam and StarTeam Server 5.2+ (stcmd move status)

Remove files (stcmd remove)

Lock and unlock a server (stcmd server mode)

Specify which type of client-side status to use (stcmd set personal options)

Update the status of files (stcmd update status)

Use ? to display the options available with the command. For example, stcmd ? displays the general syntax for stcmd and stcmd add ? displays the options available when adding files. (Using stcmd and stcmd add without the ? also works.)

Note: Files can be merged as part of stcmd co, the check out command. Use its merge and hook options. You can also merge files using the View Comparison utility and the viewmerge command line.
